title: 109_hr4623
content: The Act titled "Clean Alternatives for Energy Independence Act of 2005" repeals tax subsidies for oil and gas from the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 is repealed, including provisions related to temporary expensing for equipment used in refining liquid fuels, pass through deductions for small refiner cooperatives, treatment of natural gas distribution and gathering lines as property, determination of small refiner exceptions to oil depletion deduction, and amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be applied as if the provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 had never been enacted. SEC. 3 increases fuel cell tax incentives for residential and business uses. For residential use, the maximum credit is raised from $500 to $1,000. For business use, the credit for qualified fuel cell property is increased from $500 to $1,000, and the termination date is extended from December 31, 2007, to December 31, 2012. SEC. 4 introduces alternative motor vehicle tax incentives. Increases in Credit for new qualified fuel cell motor vehicles under section 30B of the Code: $8,000 to $16,000, $10,000 to $20,000, $20,000 to $40,000, and $40,000 to $80,000. Clause (i) amended from $1,000 to $2,000. The amendment increases the credit amounts for various clauses under section 30B of the Code, doubling the values from $2,000 to $4,000, $3,000 to $6,000, $3,500 to $7,000, and $4,000 to $8,000. This applies to new advanced lean burn technology motor vehicles. The amendment increases credit amounts under section 30B of the Code, doubling values for fuel economy and conservation credits. The amendment increases credit amounts for hybrid and advanced lean burn technology vehicles, as well as alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. The values are doubled, with increases ranging from $250 to $2,000 and from 60,000 to 120,000 units. The amendment increases credit amounts for hybrid and advanced lean burn technology vehicles, as well as alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. The values are doubled, with increases ranging from $250 to $2,000 and from $30,000 to $60,000. Extensions of incentives include extending deadlines for qualifying fuel cell motor vehicles and alternative fuel vehicle refueling property. The effective date for the amendments is changed from December 31, 2009 to December 31, 2011. The amendments will take effect as if they were part of the Energy Policy Act of 2005.
